questions.question: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, and right-sided weakness. Additionally, he exhibits altered sensorimotor integration and difficulty with voluntary movement control. His blood pressure is recorded at 190/110 mmHg. A CT scan of the head is performed with findings given below Based on the findings, Which artery is most likely involved in this case?
questions.explanation: artery, are frequently involved in hypertensive hemorrhages. These arteries supply deep brain structures, including the basal ganglia and internal capsule, which are critical for motor control. The patient's presentation of right-sided weakness and difficulties with voluntary movement control aligns with the involvement of these areas, making the lenticulostriate artery the most likely vessel affected. Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH) refers to bleeding that occurs within the brain parenchyma. Imaging Findings: On NCCT, intraparenchymal hemorrhage appears as a hyperdense lesion. The hemorrhage can typically be localized in regions such as the basal ganglia, particularly in the putamen and the internal capsule , which are critical for motor control and other functions. Etiology: Common Causes: Hypertension : Chronic high blood pressure is a primary risk factor, often causing small Bouchard aneurysms in the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the basal ganglia. Trauma Less Common Causes: Arteriovenous Malformations (AVMs) seen in younger individuals. Cerebral Amyloid

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with bilateral thalamic and basal ganglia symptoms, including motor weakness and sensory disturbances. MRI reveals bilateral infarcts in these regions. Which type of venous thrombosis is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation: infarcts in these regions, resulting in the motor and sensory symptoms observed in the patient. Venous Infarction territories Key distribution patterns: B/L Thalamic and basal ganglia involvement in internal cerebral vein/straight sinus thrombosis. (Option B) Affected posterolateral temporal lobe and inferior parietal lobule in the vein of Labbé /lateral venous sinus thrombosis. (Option C & D) B/L asymmetric cortical and subcortical lesions in superior sagittal sinus occlusion. (Option A) Venous Anatomy Cerebral veins are categorized into external (superficial) and internal veins, draining the outer and inner regions of the cerebral hemisphere. External Cerebral Veins Superior Cerebral Veins : Typically 8 to 12 in number, these veins drain the upper parts of the hemisphere, entering the superior sagittal sinus after piercing the arachnoid mater. Middle Cerebral Veins : Comprising four veins (two superficial and two deep), these veins drain the lateral sulcus, connecting to the cavernous sinus, superior sagittal sinus (Trolard) , and transverse sinus (Labbe) . The deep veins merge with the anterior cerebral vein to form the basal vein . Inferior Cerebral Veins : Numerous smaller veins that drain the inferior surfaces of the hemisphere into nearby dural venous sinuses. Additional Veins Anterior Cerebral Vein : Drains parts of the medial surface alongside the anterior cerebral artery. Basal Vein (of Rosenthal) : Formed by the anterior cerebral, deep middle cerebral, and striate veins, this vein runs around the midbrain and drains into the great cerebral vein (of Galen), receiving tributaries from various brain structures. Internal Cerebral Veins Located on either side of the midline in the tela choroidea of the 3rd ventricle. Formed at the interventricular foramen (of Monro) by the thalamostriate, septal, and choroidal veins. Drain specific brain regions: Thalamostriate (thalamus and basal ganglia) Septal (septum pellucidum) Choroidal (choroid plexus). Unite beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum to form the great cerebral vein . Great Cerebral Vein of Galen A single vein (about 2 cm long) formed by the internal cerebral veins. Receives basal veins and joins the inferior sagittal sinu s to form the straight sinus . Tributaries include: Internal cerebral veins Basal veins Veins from the colliculi (tectum of the midbrain) Veins from the cerebellum and adjacent occipital lobes

This finding aligns well with the clinical suspicion of CVT in this patient, given her symptoms and risk factors (H/o contraception). Central venous sinus thrombosis CVT should be suspected in patients presenting with headaches, seizures, or encephalopathy. Can occur in superficial or deep dural venous sinuses, affecting either isolated veins or as part of broader venous sinus thrombosis. Factors like intracranial infections , trauma, dehydration, pregnancy , oral contraceptives , smoking, and vasculitis (e.g., Behçet disease) can trigger CVT. If absent, a thrombophilia screening is necessary. CT Findings : The empty delta sign , visible in contrast-enhanced CT scans, indicates dural venous sinus thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus as a triangular filling defect outlined by contrast, representing a thrombus. Chronic Infarct Radiological Imaging: Development of encephalomalacia and volume loss, causing enlargement of adjacent sulci and ventricles. CT and MRI: signal intensity approaches that of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Rarely, cystic encephalomalacia can occur, sometimes with paradoxical mass effect (more common in children). Wallerian degeneration: may be visible as T2 hyperintensity in the ipsilateral corticospinal tract with asymmetrical brainstem atrophy. (Option A ruled out) Contralateral cerebellar volume loss can occur with large middle cerebellar artery infarcts. (Option D ruled out) Dystrophic

questions.question: A 64-year-old male presents with left-sided weakness and speech difficulty for 8 hours. NCCT shows no hemorrhage, and CTAngiography reveals a proximal MCA occlusion. DWI shows a large infarct volume (>70 ml). According to the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

options.B: Continue with tPA infusion and monitor
options.C: Consider perfusion imaging with CT or MRI

questions.explanation: perfusion imaging with CT or MRI may be considered. Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm: Acute Ischemic Stroke: Stroke is an acute episode of focal neurological dysfunction that persists for more than 24 hours. Radiological Findings CT Scan Investigation of choice. Characterized by cytotoxic edema, leading to significant but subtle changes in imaging. This condition represents intracellular edema, which causes: Loss of gray matter/white matter differentiation. Effacement of cortical sulci. Early ischemic lesion hypodensity on CT is the hallmark of acute brain infarction, indicating irreversible tissue damage and continual net water uptake. Wedge shaped acute infarct. A thrombus in the proximal middle cerebral artery (MCA) may be visible during the acute phase. The thrombus appears as hyperattenuation on the CT scan. Objectives of Non-Enhanced Cranial CT in Acute Stroke: Exclude hemorrhage to allow aspirin therapy. Exclude alternative causes of neurological deficit. Assess infarct volume and calculate ASPECTS (Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score). Detecting a hyperdense vessel. Confirm infarct matches the clinical timeline and is not subacute. Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI) Has high sensitivity and specificity, detecting parenchymal hyperintensity as early as 5 minutes after infarction onset. Determines area of penumbra. DWI must be interpreted with an apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map. Restricted diffusion in acute infarct appears bright on DWI and dark on the ADC map. In rare cases, DWI-positive areas may not progress to infarction after early recanalization treatments (IV agents or mechanical thrombectomy).

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden right-sided weakness and speech difficulty, starting 1 hour ago. A non-contrast CT scan is performed and is shown below. Which of the following signs is marked (arrow) in this case?
questions.explanation: an early finding on a non-contrast CT scan in cases of posterior circulation stroke. Hyperacute Ischemic Stroke: Patients who present within 6 hours of stroke onset fall into this category. Radiologic Findings: Top of basilar syndrome: Basilar artery may also appear dense in posterior circulation infarcts . Dense Artery Sign: (Option D) Earliest detectable sign on CT, caused by a fresh thrombus occluding the vessel. Can be seen at the onset of stroke (ictus). May rapidly disappear if the thrombus disperses. Correlates with large infarcts and poor outcomes when found in the proximal MCA or terminal ICA. Sylvian fissure dot sign (Option A): better prognosis if limited to an MCA branch within the Sylvian fissure. Early Parenchymal Signs: reduced gray matter density and brain swelling

questions.question: A 75-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The emergency physician needs to determine the best initial imaging modality to assess for an acute ischemic stroke and potential hemorrhage. Which imaging technique should be performed first?
questions.explanation: out hemorrhage Approach to Stroke: Investigations of Stroke: Non-Contrast CT (Option C) CT Angiography (Option B) MRI (Option A) Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: loss of differentiation between gray and white matter. Loss of Insular Ribbon Sign: seen when the middle cerebral artery is involved, with the insula showing early changes. Hyperdense Vessel Sign: In hyperacute strokes, the thrombus appears dense, causing hyperattenuation of the occluded segment of the MCA. CT scan can also reveal whether there is bleeding in the brain or damage to brain cells resulting from a stroke. Provides high-resolution imaging of the vascular tree from the aortic arch to intracranial vessels. Allows for functional perfusion imaging and assessment of collaterals. Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: restricted diffusion on diffusion weighted imaging. Is observed within a few minutes of arterial occlusion. Can identify changes in brain tissue and damage to brain cells. Uses: Diagnosis of major stroke. To identify a contraindication to treatment, like hemorrhage or large infarct. To identify stroke mimic such as brain tumor. Use: Detection of large vessel occlusion (LVO). Uses: Most sensitive technique for acute ischemic stroke detection. Used in imaging diagnosis of minor stroke Typically during follow-up. CT perfusion (CTP) or perfusion computed tomography (PCT): Time-resolved images of blood flow Display format is perfusion maps, including cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and mean transit time. Used to identify and quantify the volume of infarcted core and penumbra. MR Angiography (Option D) : Used in patients with a contraindication to contrast or a non-diagnostic CTA.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache and loss of consciousness. An MRI is performed shortly after the incident and shows a hyperintense lesion on T1-weighted images and a hypointense lesion on T2-weighted images, consistent with an acute hematoma. What would be the phase of blood in this condition?
questions.explanation: deoxyhemoglobin phase . Intracranial Hemorrhage Appearance on MRI: The appearance of intracranial hemorrhage on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is influenced by: The age of the hematoma. The type of MRI sequence used (T1 or T2 weighted). As a hematoma ages, hemoglobin transforms through several forms: Oxyhemoglobin Deoxyhemoglobin Methemoglobin Eventually breaking down into ferritin and hemosiderin. Stages of Hemorrhage: Hyperacute: Characterized by intracellular oxyhemoglobin . (Option B) Acute: Features intracellular deoxyhemoglobin . Early Subacute: Contains intracellular methemoglobin . (Option C) Late Subacute: Comprises extracellular methemoglobin . Chronic: Consists of ferritin and hemosiderin . (Option D) Magnetic Properties: Magnetic susceptibility effects cause short T2 values observed in intracellular deoxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin, or hemosiderin. T2 shortening can also occur due to hemoconcentration and clot retraction. The most sensitive sequence of MRI detecting hemorrhage is susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) as it has a high sensitivity to blood products and hemosiderin.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and headache. A CT scan of the brain is performed which shows as follows: The radiologist notes a characteristic appearance of increased spacing between the frontal lobes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: the appearance of mountain peaks which points to the diagnosis of pneumocephalus i.e., air within the cranial cavity . Pneumocephalus/Tension pneumocephalus: Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity . It most frequently occurs as a result of traumatic head injuries . Tension pneumocephalus can be identified on imaging by: Compression of the frontal lobes. Increased spacing between the frontal lobes in the interhemispheric area. This condition is commonly referred to as the "Mount Fuji sign" because its appearance resembles the famous mountain peak in Japan. Carotid-cavernous fistula (Option D): Classification : Carotid-cavernous fistulas (CCFs) are categorized as either direct or indirect . Direct CCF: Involves a direct connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus. Indirect CCF: Occurs when branches of the ICA or external carotid artery (ECA) connect to the cavernous sinus. Causes : Trauma : Skull base

questions.question: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He presents with loss of consciousness, altered mental status, decerebrate posturing, and widespread cerebral edema. A CT scan returns normal. After intubation, which MRI sequence is preferred for evaluating the extent of his neurological injuries?
questions.explanation: with DAI , typically resulting from acceleration-deceleration forces in RTA. The normal CT scan indicates potential injuries not visible on CT, such as axonal damage , which can be better detected with T2-weighted MRI. This sequence highlights areas of high water content, aiding in the identification of widespread cerebral edema and hemorrhagic lesions. Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from rapid acceleration and deceleration forces, commonly seen in cases of severe trauma, such as road traffic accidents (RTAs). It primarily affects the white matter of the brain, leading to widespread damage to axonal fibers. Radiological Features MRI It is the investigation of choice for diagnosing diffuse axonal injury (DAI), particularly using Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) . This sequence is sensitive to magnetic susceptibility changes, effectively detecting small hemorrhagic foci. On SWI, black areas represent hemorrhage, appearing as blooming due to blood product accumulation, indicating diffuse axonal injury. T2-weighted MRI is valuable for assessing DAI, as it reveals hyperintense areas of axonal injury and edema, highlighting brain damage and secondary changes from the injury. The combination of SWI and T2-weighted MRI enhances diagnostic accuracy, enabling a comprehensive evaluation of DAI and its structural effects on the brain. CT Findings: In most cases of DAI, CT scans may appear normal . However, in certain instances, they can show punctate hemorrhages, which are small spots of bleeding that indicate areas of axonal damage. Clinical Presentation Patients with DAI typically present with a poor or worsening Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score following trauma. This deterioration in consciousness is indicative of significant brain injury. Adams grading classification for the severity of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) The severity of DAI can be classified using Adams grading, which assesses the extent of axonal damage. Grade Location of Injury Description Prognosis I Gray matter and white matter interface Involves the initial site of axonal injury. Relatively better prognosis II Corpus callosum Involves the critical structure connecting the two hemispheres. Suggests more severe disruption of axonal pathways. Worse prognosis than Grade I III Brain stem Involves the brain stem, which can significantly affect vital functions. Associated with the worst prognosis T1-weighted MRI (T1W) (Option A): T1-weighted images provide detailed anatomical information but are not optimal for visualizing edema and diffuse changes associated with widespread brain injury. FLAIR MRI (Option B): While FLAIR imaging suppresses the signal from cerebrospinal fluid and can highlight certain lesions, it is not the primary sequence for detecting widespread edema and damage resulting from trauma. questions.question: Assertion (A): On CT scan, the bone cortex appears black, while on MRI, it appears white. Reason (R): The appearance of structures on CT and MRI depends on the density of tissues and the presence of hydrogen atoms. Assertion (A).

options.B: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but Reason (R) is not the correct explanation of
options.C: Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.
options.D: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are false.

questions.explanation: scans measure tissue density, and bones are dense structures that absorb X-rays heavily, thus appearing white. On MRI, the bone cortex typically appears black due to the lack of free hydrogen atoms needed for generating MRI signals. Reason: The reason is true, as the appearance of tissues on CT depends on tissue density (denser structures appear whiter), and on MRI, it depends on the presence of hydrogen atoms (more hydrogen results in a stronger signal). Feature CT (Computed Tomography) MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) Principle Based on differential absorption of X-rays by tissues (denser tissues absorb more X-rays) Based on the alignment of hydrogen protons in tissues in response to a magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses Imaging Time Faster Slower, can take 30 minutes to over an hour Bone cortex appearance: White (due to dense bone absorbing X-rays) Dark (lacks hydrogen protons) Applications Best for: Acute bleeding, skull fractures, calcifications, hyperacute stroke Emergency use: Ideal for emergencies due to speed Best for: Soft tissue details, brain tumors, demyelinating diseases, subacute/chronic ischemia Emergency use: Not typically used in emergencies (except for soft tissue analysis) Detection of Acute Hemorrhage Highly sensitive for detecting acute hemorrhage Less sensitive for acute hemorrhage, but can be used after a few days Evaluation of Edema Limited sensitivity to subtle edema Excellent for detecting edema and differentiating tissue types Stroke Detection Good for detecting stroke in hyperacute phase (hours) Better for detecting ischemia in subacute and chronic stages (days to weeks) Contrast Agent Used Iodine-based contrast agents (risk of allergy or kidney issues) Gadolinium-based contrast agents (caution in renal failure)

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a head injury sustained during a fall. He is alert, opens his eyes to speech, follows commands, and is oriented but complains of a mild headache. On assessment, he opens his eyes spontaneously, is verbally coherent but slightly disoriented, and follows motor commands. There are no focal neurological deficits, bleeding disorders, seizures, or intoxication. Based on the clinical findings and his GCS score, what is the next appropriate step in management?

options.C: Observation with repeat neurological assessment every 4 hours

questions.explanation: (Eye = 4, Verbal = 4, Motor = 5), indicating a mild head injury. As there are no additional risk factors per the ACR guidelines, the next best step is close observation with repeated neurological assessments rather than immediate imaging. CT Imaging Guidelines for Head Trauma GCS Score TBI Severity 13-15 Mild TBI 9-12 Moderate TBI 3-8 Severe TBI In cases of penetrating cranial injury, a head CT is recommended immediately, regardless of GCS. Indications for Head CT For patients with mild to moderate TBI (GCS 13-12) , the decision to perform a CT scan depends on the presence of additional risk factors . The ACR guidelines state that a head CT should be performed if any one of the following "ABCDEF" criteria are met. A ge >60 years B lood coagulopathy C lavicle or supra-clavicular injury D rugs or neurological deficits E pilepsy or post-traumatic seizure F ocal neurological deficits G eneric brain-related complaints (e.g., headache, vomiting) These additional findings serve as red flags, warranting imaging to prevent delayed diagnosis of significant brain injuries. Severe TBI or Penetrating Injury In the context of severe TBI (GCS 3-8) or penetrating cranial injury, a head CT is indicated immediately due to the high risk of life-threatening intracranial injuries. Immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation (Option A): This option is incorrect as intubation is typically reserved for patients with severe traumatic brain injury (GCS ≤ 8) or those at risk of airway compromise. The patient's GCS of 13, indicating a mild head injury, does not meet the criteria for intubation. CT scan of the head (Option B): According to the American College of Radiology (ACR) guidelines, a head CT scan is typically reserved for patients with a GCS score between 13-15 if additional risk factors are present, a CT scan is not immediately necessary. Initiate anticonvulsant therapy (Option D): Anticonvulsants are not routinely indicated unless there is a history of seizures or a high risk of post-traumatic seizures, which the patient does not exhibit here. Reference: https://www.acr.org/-/media/ACR/NOINDEX/RSCAN/Minor-Ped-head-trauma.pdf

questions.question: A patient comes with his MR angiography brain report to the clinic. Identify the marked artery in this image.

Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) There are various types of MR angiograms based on different principles and can be classified into non-contrast and contrast enhanced methods. Non-contrast MRA Contrast enhanced (CE) MRA Time-of-flight (TOF) imaging: It is the most prevalent method for Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) in clinical practice. Phase-contrast MRA: It is more sensitive for identifying slow blood flow and useful for imaging cerebral veins (MR venography or MRV). Effective for detecting dural venous sinus thrombosis and venous stenoses. MRA combined with gadolinium-based contrast agents is called contrast-enhanced (CE) MRA. Excellent for quickly visualizing the carotid and vertebral arteries where a large field of view (FOV) is necessary. Reduces artifacts caused by turbulent or slow flow. Useful for assessing arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), aneurysms , and intracranial stenosis . questions.question: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

options.A: It is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT for diagnosing stroke
options.B: It is used to resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging
options.C: It diagnoses spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative
options.D: It can be used for embolization of AVMs and fistulas

questions.explanation: investigation along with non-contrast CT for the diagnosis in acute stroke protocols and not DSA. Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) Clinical applications Acute stroke protocols : CTA is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT and CT perfusion (CTP) for evaluating stroke. It is used to detect dynamic contrast extravasation indicative of active hemorrhage . It is highly sensitive (>90%) for intracranial aneurysms , particularly in subarachnoid hemorrhage cases. It is also effective for assessing carotid artery stenosis , cervical artery dissection , and intracranial vascular stenosis Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) Applications Resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging (CTA or MRA). (Option B) Diagnosing spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative. (Option C) Evaluate younger patients with intraparenchymal hemorrhage for underlying arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). DSA supports a variety of endovascular treatments, including: Clot retrieval for acute ischemic stroke Treatment of brain aneurysms (coiling, stenting, flow diversion) Embolization of AVMs and fistulas (Option D) Tumor embolization and stenting of intracranial arterial stenoses Intra-arterial therapies for vasospasm

questions.question: Match the following structures with their corresponding CT score. Structure CT score in HU a) Air 1) 0 b) Water 2) -1000 c) Grey Matter 3) 700 to 3000 d) Bone 4) 37 to 45
questions.explanation: 3000 Housenfield unit (HU): In each slice of a CT scan, every tiny cube of tissue (called a voxel) is given a CT number. This number is based on how much the x-rays are blocked by that tissue, compared to distilled water at 0°C and 1 bar of pressure, and is measured in Hounsfield Units (HU). The ones with a lower CT number appear the darkest, and the ones with a higher CT number appear brighter. The values of some structures are as follows: Structure CT score (HU) Air -1000 Water 0 CSF 8 to 15 White matter 20 to 30 Blood 30 to 45 Grey matter 37 to 45 Contrast 100 to 300 Bone 700 (cancellous) to 3000 (inner and outer tables) Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology: A Textbook of Medical Imaging, 7th edition, page: 1369, 1371-1372, 1374-1375

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents with persistent headaches and cognitive decline. An MRI reveals a suspicious mass in the parietal lobe. To further characterize the mass, an MR spectroscopy (MRS) is performed which shows: Which of the following interpretations is most accurate regarding the metabolic changes observed in MR spectroscopy?

options.A: The elevated choline levels suggest high cellular turnover
options.B: The decreased NAA indicates significant neuronal viability
options.C: The absence of any metabolites in the spectrum indicates healthy brain tissue
options.D: Raised creatinine levels show low metabolic activity

questions.explanation: suggesting increased cellular turnover. MR Spectroscopy It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T. Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues. Metabolite Markers N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) : indicates neuronal viability. (Option B) Choline : represents cell membrane composition and cellular turnover . Creatine : found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D) Lipids : released during cell membrane damage. Lactate : signifies anaerobic metabolism. In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C) Clinical Applications Choline is raised in malignancies. Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium. MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including: Grading of tumors. Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects. Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with progressive memory loss and word-finding difficulty shows language deficits on a neurological exam. The physician orders an MRI to map language centers before treatment. Which MRI technique is most appropriate for this?
questions.explanation: detect the language center in the brain in this scenario and also in preoperative assessments. Functional MRI (fMRI) It is used for noninvasive mapping of brain function related to specific tasks (e.g., motor, language, visual, memory). It provides insights into functional localization, anatomical variations, and the effects of diseases and adaptations and is important for preoperative assessments in tumors, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), and epilepsy surgery. Principle Increased neural activity during a task I Localized rise in blood flow for oxygen and glucose supply I I Oxygenated hemoglobin (oxyHb) I deoxygenated hemoglobin (deoxyHb) I Changes in magnetization I Measured by blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) effect . The comparison between the BOLD effect measured at rest and while doing a particular function gives the precise functional localization of nerve cells to be color-mapped . Applications Detects functionality in diseases like Alzheimer’s. Presurgical assessment for brain tumor and AVM surgeries. Preepilepsy surgery assessment of language centre localization and hemispheric dominance. Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTR)/Tractography (Option A) : It is a variation of the diffusion-weighted imaging technique. This is useful in analyzing the principal white matter pathways in the brain, connections of various regions of the brain, and their disorders. Susceptibility- Weighted Imaging (SWI) (Option B) It incorporates T2*-signal intensity losses in images. This is highly sensitive for detecting variations in tissue structure caused by differences in susceptibility. Effectively identifies substances such as Deoxygenated blood Hemosiderin Ferritin Calcium T2* T2* (T2 star) relaxation is the time taken for the decay of transverse magnetization in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), including both the irreversible T2 relaxation and additional reversible dephasing processes. T2* is always less than T2. Perfusion-Weighted Imaging (PWI) (Option D) : Perfusion-weighted imaging encompasses three methods for assessing brain tissue perfusion. It provides information about: Cerebral blood volume (CBV) Cerebral blood flow (CBF) Mean transit time (MTT) Capillary permeability, which is elevated in conditions like gliomas, metastases, and inflammatory lesions Areas of reduced perfusion (oligemic or ischemic brain tissue) Measures tissue blood flow without the need for contrast injection.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of weakness for an hour on one side of his body. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis but is not compliant with his medications. A CT scan is performed, which shows no acute hemorrhage. An MRI of the brain was performed below. Which MRI sequence is most appropriate for detecting early ischemic changes in this patient?
questions.explanation: diagnosed with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) MRI as it can detect infarcts within minutes of onset . The image also points out that it is DWI since in this method the skull is not visualized . MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) Principle When the patient is placed in an MRI machine, the protons in the body arrange themselves in a specific fashion, that is, parallel or antiparallel to the external magnetic field (B I ) . When radiofrequency (FR) waves are passed through the patient, they induce the MR coil/antenna, which is digitally processed into images. The time between each RF pulse is called the repetition time (TR). The time taken between the excitation of protons to the reading of an echo signal is called echo time (TE) . Contraindications Absolute: Cardiac pacemaker
